(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT. 
(c) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to an employee being considered for promotion who resides in the city by doing any of the 
following: 
(1) Provide notice in a written policy or procedure that is provided to employees at least 10 
business days before use of an AEDT;

Document 22: 10 
 
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT.  
(d) To comply with § 20-871(b)(3) of the Code, an employer or employment agency must: 
(1) Provide information on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous 
manner about its AEDT data retention policy, the type of data collected for the AEDT, and the 
source of the data; 
(2) Post instructions on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
for how to make a written request for such information, and if a written request is received, 
provide such information within 30 days; and 
(3) Provide an explanation to a candidate for employment or employee being considered for 
promotion why disclosure of such information would violate local, state, or federal law, or 
interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

Example 2: An employment agency has been using an AEDT for 6 months. The bias audit the 
employment agency relied on before its first use of the AEDT was conducted 10 months ago using test 
data. The employment agency will need an updated bias audit if it will continue to use the AEDT once 12 
months have passed since the bias audit it first relied on was conducted. The employment agency’s data 
from 6 months of use of the AEDT is not sufficient on its own to conduct a statistically significant bias 
audit. The employment agency may rely on a bias audit using the historical data of other employers and 
employment agencies if it provides its 6 months of historical data to the independent auditor for use and 
consideration. The employment agency may also rely on a bias audit that uses test data. 
 
Example 3: An employer has been using an AEDT for 3 years and will soon need an updated bias audit. 
The employer has statistically significant data from its 3 years of use of the AEDT. The employer may 
rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from multiple employers if it provides its 3 years of 
historical data to the independent auditor for use and consideration. The employer may also rely on a 
bias audit conducted using historical data from its own use of the AEDT, without any data from other 
employers or employment agencies. The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test 
data.  
 
§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of 
individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.

agent_answer: To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency must provide notice to a candidate for employment at least 10 business days before using an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT). This notice can be provided on the employment section of the employer's website, in a job posting, or via U.S. mail or e-mail. Before using an AEDT, the employer or employment agency must also make publicly available on their website in a clear and conspicuous manner the distribution date of the AEDT, as well as a summary of results and impact ratios for all categories assessed by the AEDT. The AEDT may be used to screen resumes and schedule interviews for individuals in an unknown category, and to score employees, employees being considered for promotion, candidates for employment, and applicants, and to assign classifications and calculate scores. However, the AEDT may not be used if the bias audit is more than a year old, and employers or employment agencies should rely on historical data collected during the use of the AEDT by themselves or other employers or employment agencies. It is important to note that an updated bias audit will be needed before using the AEDT if the most recent audit is more than a year old. The AEDT can be used by multiple employers or agencies and was previously used to assess 15 individuals in a bias audit. The AEDT is defined by § 20-870 of the code and selects candidates for employment or promotion. It is only used to screen at an early point in the application process and assigns classifications based on the calculated score. The employer or employment agency must ensure that calculations separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on race/ethnicity and sex categories, and must calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for each category. The employer or employment agency must also ensure that the median score and selection rate for each category are calculated, and that the selection rates are compared to the most selected category. The employer or employment agency must make the bias audit publicly available upon written request, and must indicate the number of individuals assessed and the number of individuals not included in the calculations. The AEDT must be conducted using historical data, and the data must be no more than a year old before planned use.

question: What is required for an employer or employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool, and what penalties can be imposed for violations of the subchapter regarding automated employment decision tools?
reference_answer: To use an automated employment decision tool, an employer or employment agency must have conducted a bias audit of the tool within the past year and made the results publicly available. Violations of the subchapter regarding automated employment decision tools can result in civil penalties ranging from $500 for a first violation to $1,500 for each subsequent violation.

agent_answer: To use an automated employment decision tool in New York City, an employer or employment agency must comply with the requirements set forth in Section 20-871 of the code. The tool must not be derived from machine learning or assess disparate impact, and must not issue a simplified output that overrules conclusions derived from other factors. The tool must not be used as the sole criterion for employment or promotion, and must not be used to assign classification or calculate scores, screen resumes or schedule interviews, or be used for individuals in unknown categories. A bias audit must be conducted pursuant to Section 5-301, and must use historical data and test data to ensure that calculations separately calculate the impact of the tool on race/ethnicity and sex categories. The audit must calculate the impact ratio and selection rate for each category, and indicate the number of individuals assessed not included in calculations. The audit must also calculate the median score, selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category, and compare selection rates to the most selected category. The tool must not be used more than a year before planned use. Civil penalties of up to $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and up to $1,500 for each subsequent violation may be imposed for failure to comply with these requirements.

The ground truth specifies that the audit results must be made publicly available and does not mention several of the conditions listed by the agent.

question: What is the definition of 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' and what is a 'Bias audit'?
reference_answer: The term 'automated employment decision tool' means any computational process, derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation, that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. A 'bias audit' means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported by employers.

Section 1.  Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to add Subchapter T to read

Subchapter T: Automated Employment Decision Tools 
§ 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
 
Automated Employment Decision Tool. “Automated employment decision tool” or “AEDT” means 
“Automated employment decision tool” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code where the phrase “to 
substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means: 
i. 
to rely solely on a simplified output (score, tag, classification, ranking, etc.), with no other 
factors considered; or 
ii. 
 to use a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where the simplified output is weighted 
more than any other criterion in the set; or   
iii. 
to use a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including 
human decision-making.  
  
Bias Audit. “Bias audit” means “Bias audit” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.  
 
Candidate for Employment. “Candidate for employment” means a person who has applied for a specific 
employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the 
employer or employment agency.  
 
Category. “Category” means any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant 
to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States Code as specified in part 1602.7 of 
title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as designated on the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission Employer Information Report EEO-1. 
 
Code. “Code” means the Administrative Code of the City of New York. 
 
Distribution Date. “Distribution date” means the date the employer or employment agency began using 
a specific AEDT.  
 
Employment Decision. “Employment decision” means “Employment decision” as defined by § 20-870 
of the Code.

249.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported by employers."}], 'fake_fact': None}
agent_answer:
An 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' in the context of Local Law 144 in New York City refers to any computational process that uses machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence to issue simplified output, such as a score, classification, or recommendation, that substantially assists or replaces discretionary decision making for employment decisions that impact natural persons. However, it does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons.

A 'Bias audit' is an impartial evaluation conducted by an independent auditor to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of federal regulations. The audit must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category that is required to be reported on to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“EEOC”) pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report, and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to determine an impact ratio. The bias audit must be conducted no more than one year prior to the use of the tool, and information about the bias audit must be publicly available. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment agencies only in certain circumstances, as specified in section 5-302 of the law. If insufficient historical data is available, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data, as long as the summary of results of the bias audit explains why historical data was not used and describes how the test data used was generated and obtained.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides a detailed explanation of both terms but includes excessive detail and specific legal references that are not present in the ground truth. The ground truth is more concise and does not include the same level of specificity regarding the bias audit process.
reason_method2: The generated answer accurately defines both 'Automated Employment Decision Tool' and 'Bias audit' in detail, covering all components of the user query without any factual errors.

question: What are the requirements for a bias audit and what is test data?
reference_answer: The requirements for a bias audit include calculating the selection rate and impact ratio for each category. Test data is the data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data.
reference_context:
Document 5: These rules establish that a bias audit of an AEDT must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and 
sex category that is required to be reported on to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (“EEOC”) 
pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report, and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to 
determine an impact ratio. These calculations are consistent with Section 1607.4 of the EEOC Uniform 
Guidelines on Employee Selection Procedures. See 29 C.F.R. § 1607.4. These rules generally clarify obligations 
of employers and employment agencies under the new law. 
 
Specifically, these new rules will: 
 
Define terms; 
 
Clarify the requirements for a bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for the published results of the required bias audit;  
 
Clarify the requirements for notices that employers and employment agencies must provide to employees 
and candidates for employment; and  
 
Clarify other obligations for the employer or employment agency.  
 
The Department initially proposed a version of these rules in September 2022. The Department received 
comments from the public, including from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and 
advocacy organizations. Various issues raised in the comments led to a second version of the proposed rules, 
published in December 2022. Those changes included:  
 
Modifying the definition of AEDT to ensure greater focus; 
 
Clarifying that an “independent auditor” may not be employed or have a financial interest in an employer 
or employment agency that seeks to use or continue to use an AEDT or in a vendor that developed or 
distributed the AEDT; 
 
Revising the required calculation to be performed where an AEDT scores candidates;

Document 6: 2 
 
 
Clarifying that the required “impact ratio” must be calculated separately to compare sex categories, 
race/ethnicity categories, and intersectional categories; 
 
Clarifying the types of data that may be used to conduct a bias audit; 
 
Clarifying that multiple employers using the same AEDT may rely on the same bias audit so long as they 
provide historical data, if available, for the independent auditor to consider in such bias audit; and 
 
Clarifying that an AEDT may not be used if its most recent bias audit is more than a year old; 
 
The Department received comments about the second version of the proposed rule from the public, including 
from employers, employment agencies, law firms, AEDT developers, and advocacy organizations. Various 
issues raised in the comments resulted in changes that are present in these final rules. These changes include: 
 
Modifying the definition of “machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence” 
to expand its scope; 
 
Adding a requirement that the bias audit indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are 
not included in the calculations because they fall within an unknown category, and requiring that number 
be included in the summary of results; 
 
Allowing an independent auditor to exclude a category that comprises less than 2% of the data being 
used for the bias audit from the calculations of impact ratio; 
 
Clarifying the examples of a bias audit; 
 
Clarifying when an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit conducted using the 
historical data of other employers or employment agencies; 
 
Providing examples of when an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit conducted with 
historical data, test data, or historical data from other employers and employment agencies; 
 
Clarifying that the number of applicants in a category and scoring rate of a category, if applicable, must 
be included in the summary of results. 
 
New material is underlined. 
[Deleted material is in brackets.] 
 
“Shall” and “must” denote mandatory requirements and may be used interchangeably in the rules of this 
department, unless otherwise specified or unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.

§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category.

agent_answer: To conduct a bias audit in accordance with Local Law 144 in New York City, the audit must evaluate an automated employment decision tool in accordance with § 20-870 of the code. The audit must be conducted using historical data of the AEDT, but if there is insufficient historical data available, test data may be used instead. Test data is defined as data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. The test data must be generated and obtained in a manner that is described in the summary of results. The bias audit must have been conducted no more than one year prior to its use or planned use, and it must not give rise to a separate violation and must not be used in violation of Section 20-871. The data used to conduct a bias audit must be from one or more employers or employment agencies, and must ensure that calculations separately calculate the impact of AEDT on race/ethnicity and sex categories. The audit must calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for each category, and must compare selection rates to the most selected category. Additionally, the audit must calculate the median score and scoring rate, and indicate the number of individuals assessed not included in calculations.
reason_method2: The generated answer provides a comprehensive overview of the requirements for a bias audit and correctly defines test data, addressing all components of the query with minimal errors.

question: What must an employer or employment agency provide in a bias audit and what are the options for providing notice to a candidate for employment?
reference_answer: An employer or employment agency must provide the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results. They can provide notice on the employment section of its website, in a job posting, or via U.S. mail or e-mail.

(2) Post instructions on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner

interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

agent_answer: If an employer or employment agency conducts a bias audit using an AEDT, they must provide notice to candidates for employment at least 10 business days before use of the AEDT. The notice should be provided via email, U.S. mail, job posting, or on their website in a clear and conspicuous manner. Candidates being considered for promotion or recommended for an interview should also receive the notice. The bias audit results should rely on at least 3 years of historical data and not on test data. The summary of the results of the bias audit should include the source and explanation of the data used, the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT that fall within an unknown category, and the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios for all categories assessed by the AEDT. The results and distribution date should be posted for at least 6 months after the latest use of the AEDT. The summary of results should describe how the test data was generated, include the independent auditor's justification for exclusion, and explain why historical data was not used. The results must be made publicly available, and the employer or employment agency must include the number of applicants or candidates assessed by the AEDT, the number of individuals assessed by the AEDT, and the impact ratios for all categories assessed by the AEDT. The bias audit should calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category. The AEDT can only be used to screen at an early point in the application process and can be used to score employees, employees being considered for promotion, candidates for employment, applicants, and candidates. The AEDT may not be used if the bias audit is more than a year old, and employers or employment agencies may use the AEDT after providing at least 10 business days notice. The bias audit may be conducted using test data or historical data, and the results should be conducted and distributed within 6 months of the latest use of the AEDT.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer is overly detailed and includes incorrect information about the requirements for a bias audit and notice provisions. question: What are the requirements and purpose of conducting a bias audit?

agent_answer: According to Local Law 144 of 2021 in New York City, employers and employment agencies must conduct a bias audit of an automated employment decision tool (AEDT) before using it to screen candidates or employees for an employment decision. The purpose of the bias audit is to ensure that the AEDT does not have a discriminatory effect on any protected group and to evaluate its potential disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category. The bias audit must be conducted pursuant to Section 5-301 and must use either test data or historical data. The AEDT must be evaluated using the criteria defined by § 20-870 of the code, and the results of the bias audit must be made publicly available on the employer or employment agency's website prior to the use of the AEDT. The bias audit must calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category separately and compare the selection rates to the most selected category to determine an impact ratio. The AEDT must exclude junk email filters and issue a simplified output. The computational process used to evaluate the AEDT is derived from machine learning. The bias audit must be conducted no more than a year before planned use and must not give rise to a separate violation of Section 20-871.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides detailed information about the bias audit process but does not mention the requirement to exclude categories representing less than 2% of the data, which is part of the ground truth. Additionally, the purpose described in the agent's answer is more focused on ensuring non-discrimination rather than assessing impact on different categories.
reason_method2: The generated answer provides relevant information about the requirements and purpose of a bias audit but includes excessive detail and some inaccuracies regarding the specific requirements mentioned in the reference answer.

question: What is the meaning of 'simplified output' and 'impact ratio'?
reference_answer: 'Simplified output' refers to a prediction or classification in the fields of machine learning, statistical modelling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence. 'Impact ratio' can either refer to the selection rate for a category divided by the selection rate of the most selected category, or the scoring rate for a category divided by the scoring rate for the highest scoring category.
reference_context:
Document 10: Scoring Rate. “Scoring Rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above 
the sample’s median score, where the score has been calculated by an AEDT. 
 
Screen. “Screen” means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or 
employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion 
process.  
 
Selection Rate. “Selection rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category are either selected to 
move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by an AEDT. Such rate may be calculated 
by dividing the number of individuals in the category moving forward or assigned a classification by the 
total number of individuals in the category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.  
 
Example. If 100 Hispanic women apply for a position and 40 are selected for an interview after use of an 
AEDT, the selection rate for Hispanic women is 40/100 or 40%.  
 
Simplified output. “Simplified output” means a prediction or classification as specified in the definition 
for “machine learning, statistical modelling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence.” A simplified output 
may take the form of a score (e.g., rating a candidate’s estimated technical skills), tag or categorization 
(e.g., categorizing a candidate’s resume based on key words, assigning a skill or trait to a candidate), 
recommendation (e.g., whether a candidate should be given an interview), or ranking (e.g., arranging a 
list of candidates based on how well their cover letters match the job description). It does not refer to the 
output from analytical tools that translate or transcribe existing text, e.g., convert a resume from a PDF 
or transcribe a video or audio interview.

at any point during the bias audit, has a direct financial interest or a material indirect 
financial interest in an employer or employment agency that seeks to use or continue to 
use the  AEDT or in a vendor that developed or distributed the AEDT. 
 
Impact Ratio. “Impact ratio” means either (1) the selection rate for a category divided by the selection 
rate of the most selected category or (2) the scoring rate for a category divided by the scoring rate for the 
highest scoring category.

statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence” means a group of mathematical, computer-
based techniques:  
i. 
that generate a prediction, meaning an expected outcome for an observation, such as an 
assessment of a candidate’s fit or likelihood of success, or that generate a classification, 
meaning an assignment of an observation to a group, such as categorizations based on 
skill sets or aptitude; and  
ii. 
for which a computer at least in part identifies the inputs, the relative importance placed 
on those inputs, and, if applicable, other parameters for the models in order to improve 
the accuracy of the prediction or classification. 
 
Scoring Rate. “Scoring Rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category receive a score above 
the sample’s median score, where the score has been calculated by an AEDT. 
 
Screen. “Screen” means to make a determination about whether a candidate for employment or 
employee being considered for promotion should be selected or advanced in the hiring or promotion 
process.  
 
Selection Rate. “Selection rate” means the rate at which individuals in a category are either selected to 
move forward in the hiring process or assigned a classification by an AEDT. Such rate may be calculated 
by dividing the number of individuals in the category moving forward or assigned a classification by the 
total number of individuals in the category who applied for a position or were considered for promotion.  
 
Example.

agent_answer: In the context of Local Law 144 in New York City, "simplified output" refers to any score, tag, categorization, recommendation, or ranking issued by an automated employment decision tool that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. "Impact ratio" is the calculation of the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category, which is defined as the selection rate for a category divided by the selection rate of the most selected category. This calculation is required to be reported to the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) pursuant to the EEO Component 1 report. These definitions are used in the context of a bias audit evaluating an automated employment decision tool and are outlined in the definitions section of the law.
correctness_reason: The agent's definitions for 'simplified output' and 'impact ratio' are overly specific to Local Law 144 and do not encompass the broader meanings as described in the ground truth.
reason_method2: The generated answer correctly defines both terms and provides relevant context, but it focuses specifically on Local Law 144, which may not be necessary for a general understanding.

question: What is a bias audit and what information should be publicly available before using an AEDT?
reference_answer: A bias audit is a process that calculates the selection rate and impact ratio of an AEDT on different categories such as sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. Before using an AEDT, an employer or employment agency must make publicly available the date of the most recent bias audit and a summary of the results, including the source and explanation of the data used, the number of individuals falling within an unknown category, and the selection rates and impact ratios for all categories.
reference_context:
Document 11: 5 
 
 
Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

bias audit conducted using historical data from its own use of the AEDT, without any data from other 
employers or employment agencies. The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.

agent_answer: To use an Automated Employment Decision Tool (AEDT), employers and employment agencies must conduct a bias audit no more than a year before planned use. The audit must evaluate the AEDT's impact on race/ethnicity and sex categories, and ensure that calculations separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on each category. The audit must also calculate the selection rate and impact ratio for each category, and compare selection rates to the most selected category. The employer or employment agency must make publicly available on their website the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT, a summary of the results, and the distribution date of the AEDT. The summary of results must include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of individuals assessed, and the selection rates and impact ratios for all categories. The summary of results and distribution date must be posted for at least 6 months after the latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision. The notice required by the code must include instructions for how an individual can request an alternative selection process or a reasonable accommodation under other laws, if available.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides excessive detail and includes specific requirements that are not mentioned in the ground truth. It also incorrectly states that the summary must include the distribution date of the AEDT and instructions for requesting alternative processes, which are not part of the ground truth.
reason_method2: The generated answer is mostly correct, addressing the components of a bias audit and the information that should be publicly available, but it includes some unnecessary details and minor inaccuracies regarding the posting duration.

question: What is the definition of 'employment decision' and what are the requirements for using an automated employment decision tool?
reference_answer: The term 'employment decision' means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city. It is unlawful for an employer or employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool unless it has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior and a summary of the results of the most recent bias audit has been made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency.
reference_context:
Document 1: Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required. In the city, any employer or employment agency that uses an automated employment decision tool to screen an employee or a
candidate who has applied for a position for an employment decision shall notify each such employee or candidate who resides in the city of the
following:
      1.   That an automated employment decision tool will be used in connection with the assessment or evaluation of such employee or candidate that
resides in the city. Such notice shall be made no less than ten business days before such use and allow a candidate to request an alternative selection
process or accommodation;
      2.   The job qualifications and characteristics that such automated employment decision tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or
employee. Such notice shall be made no less than 10 business days before such use; and
      3.   If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment
decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

employee. Such notice shall be made no less than 10 business days before such use; and
      3.   If not disclosed on the employer or employment agency's website, information about the type of data collected for the automated employment
decision tool, the source of such data and the employer or employment agency's data retention policy shall be available upon written request by a
candidate or employee. Such information shall be provided within 30 days of the written request. Information pursuant to this section shall not be
disclosed where such disclosure would violate local, state, or federal law, or interfere with a law enforcement investigation.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-872 Penalties.
   a.   Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more
than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500
for each subsequent violation.
   b.   Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of this section shall give rise to a separate violation of subdivision a
of section 20-871.
   c.   Failure to provide any notice to a candidate or an employee in violation of paragraphs 1, 2 or 3 of subdivision b of section 20-871 shall constitute a
separate violation.
   d.   A proceeding to recover any civil penalty authorized by this subchapter is returnable to any tribunal established within the office of administrative
trials and hearings or within any agency of the city designated to conduct such proceedings.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-873 Enforcement.
The corporation counsel or such other persons designated by the corporation counsel on behalf of the department may initiate in any court of competent

mandating compliance with the provisions of this chapter or such other relief as may be appropriate.

agent_answer: An 'employment decision' as defined by Local Law 144 of 2021 in New York City refers to the screening of candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city. To use an automated employment decision tool, it is required that the tool has been subject to a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the planned use of such tool. The bias audit must be conducted pursuant to Section 5-301 and must evaluate the impact of the tool on race/ethnicity and sex categories separately. The audit must also ensure that calculations separately calculate the impact of the tool on each category and must use historical data while testing the tool with test data. The audit must calculate the impact ratio and selection rate for each category and indicate the number of individuals assessed not included in calculations. The results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies must be made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool. Additionally, notices must be provided to candidates or employees regarding the use of an automated employment decision tool, including information about the job qualifications and characteristics that such tool will use in the assessment of such candidate or employee.

reason_method2: The generated answer accurately defines 'employment decision' and comprehensively outlines the requirements for using an automated employment decision tool, aligning closely with the reference answer.

question: What are the requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT and what is test data?
reference_answer: The requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT are to calculate the selection rate for each race/ethnicity and sex category and compare the selection rates to determine an impact ratio. Test data is data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data.

The Department initially proposed a version of these rules in September 2022. The Department received

published in December 2022. Those changes included:

Modifying the definition of AEDT to ensure greater focus;

§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

Document 15: 7 
 
(3) Calculate the impact ratio for each category;  
(4) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision 
separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (i.e., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates); and  
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
(d) Notwithstanding the requirements of paragraphs (2) and (3) of subdivision (b) and paragraphs (3) and 
(4) of subdivision (c), an independent auditor may exclude a category that represents less than 2% of 
the data being used for the bias audit from the required calculations for impact ratio. Where such a 
category is excluded, the summary of results must include the independent auditor’s justification for the 
exclusion, as well as the number of applicants and scoring rate or selection rate for the excluded 
category.  
 
Example: An employer uses an AEDT to score applicants for “culture fit.” To do so, the employer must 
ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than a year before the use of the AEDT.

agent_answer: To conduct a bias audit of an automated employment decision tool (AEDT) in accordance with Local Law 144 in New York City, the audit must be conducted no more than one year prior to use or planned use of the AEDT. The audit must evaluate the AEDT's potential for disparate impact and must be conducted pursuant to Section 5-301. The AEDT must be evaluated using a computational process derived from machine learning and defined by § 20-870 of the code. The audit must ensure that calculations separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on race/ethnicity and sex categories, and must calculate the impact ratio and selection rate for each category. The audit must also calculate the median score and compare selection rates to the most selected category. The bias audit must be impartial and exclude the junk email filter, and issue a simplified output that may take the form of a score, tag, categorization, recommendation, or ranking. The AEDT must not be used in violation of Section 20-871. If there is insufficient historical data, test data may be used, which is defined as data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. The test data must be described in the summary of results and must be no more than a year before planned use. The audit must indicate the number of individuals assessed and not included in calculations.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides excessive detail and includes information not present in the ground truth, while also missing the concise summary of the requirements and definition of test data as stated in the ground truth.
reason_method2: The generated answer provides a comprehensive overview of the requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT and correctly defines test data, but it includes some extraneous details that do not directly address the user query.

question: What is the purpose of a bias audit and under what circumstances can an employer rely on it using historical data from other employers?
reference_answer: The purpose of a bias audit is to calculate the impact ratio and selection rate of an AEDT on different categories. An employer can rely on a bias audit using historical data from other employers if they provided their own historical data or if they have never used the AEDT.

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.

agent_answer: According to Local Law 144 in New York City, a bias audit of an automated employment decision tool (AEDT) must be conducted by employers and employment agencies before using it to ensure that it does not discriminate against any protected categories. The purpose of the bias audit is to evaluate the AEDT for any potential biases. The bias audit may be conducted using test data or historical data, and it is defined by § 20-870 of the code. Employers and employment agencies may rely on historical data from one or more employers or employment agencies to conduct the bias audit, but only if the employer or employment agency provided historical data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. The bias audit must ensure that calculations separately calculate the impact of the AEDT on race/ethnicity and sex categories. The AEDT may only be used to screen at an early point in the application process and to screen resumes and schedule interviews. It may be used to assess individuals in an unknown category and to select candidates for employment or promotion. However, if the most recent bias audit is more than a year old, the AEDT may not be used. The bias audit is conducted pursuant to Section 5-301 and evaluates the AEDT for any potential biases.

question: What is the definition of an automated employment decision tool and what are the requirements for using it?
reference_answer: The term 'automated employment decision tool' means any computational process, derived from machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation, that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or employee for an employment decision unless: 1. Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and 2. A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
reference_context:
Document 7: 3 
 
Section 1.  Chapter 5 of Title 6 of the Rules of the City of New York is amended to add Subchapter T to read 
as follows: 
Subchapter T: Automated Employment Decision Tools 
§ 5-300. Definitions. 
As used in this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings: 
 
Automated Employment Decision Tool. “Automated employment decision tool” or “AEDT” means 
“Automated employment decision tool” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code where the phrase “to 
substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making” means: 
i. 
to rely solely on a simplified output (score, tag, classification, ranking, etc.), with no other 
factors considered; or 
ii. 
 to use a simplified output as one of a set of criteria where the simplified output is weighted 
more than any other criterion in the set; or   
iii. 
to use a simplified output to overrule conclusions derived from other factors including 
human decision-making.  
  
Bias Audit. “Bias audit” means “Bias audit” as defined by § 20-870 of the Code.  
 
Candidate for Employment. “Candidate for employment” means a person who has applied for a specific 
employment position by submitting the necessary information or items in the format required by the 
employer or employment agency.  
 
Category. “Category” means any component 1 category required to be reported by employers pursuant 
to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States Code as specified in part 1602.7 of 
title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as designated on the Equal Employment Opportunity 
Commission Employer Information Report EEO-1. 
 
Code. “Code” means the Administrative Code of the City of New York. 
 
Distribution Date. “Distribution date” means the date the employer or employment agency began using 
a specific AEDT.  
 
Employment Decision. “Employment decision” means “Employment decision” as defined by § 20-870 
of the Code. 
 
Employment Agency. “Employment agency” means “Employment agency” as defined by 6 RCNY § 5-
249.  
 
Historical data.

Document 0: Subchapter 25: Automated Employment Decision Tools
§ 20-870 Definitions.
For the purposes of this subchapter, the following terms have the following meanings:
   Automated employment decision tool. The term "automated employment decision tool" means any computational process, derived from machine
learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence, that issues simplified output, including a score, classification, or recommendation,
that is used to substantially assist or replace discretionary decision making for making employment decisions that impact natural persons. The term
"automated employment decision tool" does not include a tool that does not automate, support, substantially assist or replace discretionary decision-
making processes and that does not materially impact natural persons, including, but not limited to, a junk email filter, firewall, antivirus software,
calculator, spreadsheet, database, data set, or other compilation of data.
   Bias audit. The term "bias audit" means an impartial evaluation by an independent auditor. Such bias audit shall include but not be limited to the
testing of an automated employment decision tool to assess the tool's disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category required to be reported
by employers pursuant to subsection (c) of section 2000e-8 of title 42 of the United States code as specified in part 1602.7 of title 29 of the code of
federal regulations.
   Employment decision. The term "employment decision" means to screen candidates for employment or employees for promotion within the city.
(L.L. 2021/144, 12/11/2021, eff. 1/1/2023)
§ 20-871 Requirements for automated employment decision tools.
   a.   In the city, it shall be unlawful for an employer or an employment agency to use an automated employment decision tool to screen a candidate or
employee for an employment decision unless:
      1.   Such tool has been the subject of a bias audit conducted no more than one year prior to the use of such tool; and
      2.   A summary of the results of the most recent bias audit of such tool as well as the distribution date of the tool to which such audit applies has been
made publicly available on the website of the employer or employment agency prior to the use of such tool.
   b.   Notices required.

agent_answer: An automated employment decision tool is a computational process that generates simplified output, such as a score or categorization, to assist or replace discretionary decision making for employment decisions that impact individuals. To use this tool in accordance with Local Law 144 in New York City, employers or employment agencies must ensure that the tool has undergone a bias audit no more than a year before planned use. The audit must calculate the impact ratio, selection rate, and median score for each race/ethnicity and sex category. The tool must also compare selection rates to the most selected category and provide notices to employees or candidates about the use of the tool, including information about the job qualifications and characteristics used in the assessment, the type and source of data collected, and the data retention policy upon written request. It is important to note that failure to comply with these requirements may result in a separate violation as defined by § 20-870 and § 20-871 of the code.

question: What is the definition of an automated employment decision tool, and what are the penalties for violating the requirements associated with it?
reference_answer: An automated employment decision tool refers to a computational process that uses machine learning, statistical modeling, data analytics, or artificial intelligence to provide simplified output for employment decisions. Violating the requirements for such tools can result in civil penalties, with a maximum penalty of $500 for a first violation and increasing penalties for subsequent violations, ranging from $500 to $1,500.

   a.   Any person that violates any provision of this subchapter or any rule promulgated pursuant to this subchapter is liable for a civil penalty of not more

agent_answer: An automated employment decision tool is a computational process that issues simplified output, such as a score, tag, categorization, recommendation, or ranking, that can be used to assist or replace discretionary decision making for employment decisions that impact natural persons. This includes prediction or classification, but excludes junk email filters. Local Law 144 in New York City imposes penalties for violating the requirements associated with the use of an automated employment decision tool. These penalties include a civil penalty of not more than $500 for a first violation and each additional violation occurring on the same day as the first violation, and not less than $500 nor more than $1,500 for each subsequent violation. Each day on which an automated employment decision tool is used in violation of the law shall give rise to a separate violation, and failure to provide any notice to a candidate or an employee in violation of certain provisions shall constitute a separate violation. The corporation counsel or designated persons may initiate any action or proceeding that may be appropriate or necessary for correction of any violation issued pursuant to the law, including mandating compliance with the provisions of the law or such other relief as may be appropriate. The automated employment decision tool can be used as one of a set of criteria or solely relied upon, and can be used to select employees for promotion, candidates for employment, or to screen resumes and schedule interviews. A specific example of an automated employment decision tool is Aedt, which was used to assess 15 individuals and is defined by § 20-870 of the code. Aedt uses historical data to score employees, candidates, and applicants, but is only used to screen at an early point in the application process. It can be used after 10 business days notice and may be used by multiple employers or agencies. A bias audit was conducted when Aedt was used to assess 15 individuals. The law requires that any automated employment decision tool must be assessed for disparate impact on persons of any component 1 category, and failure to comply with this requirement may result in penalties.

While it correctly defines an automated employment decision tool and mentions penalties, it diverges from the concise nature of the ground truth answer.

question: What is the relationship between the definition of 'test data' in a bias audit and the requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT?
reference_answer: In a bias audit, 'test data' refers to the data used for the audit that is not historical data. On the other hand, a bias audit of an AEDT requires calculating the selection rate and impact ratio for each category, including sex, race/ethnicity, and intersectional categories. Therefore, the definition of 'test data' in a bias audit is distinct from the requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT, but both are crucial components of ensuring fairness and identifying potential biases in automated systems.
reference_context:
Document 18: (a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit. If a bias audit uses test data, the summary of results of the 
bias audit must explain why historical data was not used and describe how the test data used was 
generated and obtained.  
 
Example 1: An employer is planning to use an AEDT for the first time. The employer may rely on a bias 
audit conducted using the historical data of other employers or employment agencies, or on a bias audit 
conducted using test data.

Document 19: 9 
 
Example 2: An employment agency has been using an AEDT for 6 months. The bias audit the 
employment agency relied on before its first use of the AEDT was conducted 10 months ago using test 
data. The employment agency will need an updated bias audit if it will continue to use the AEDT once 12 
months have passed since the bias audit it first relied on was conducted. The employment agency’s data 
from 6 months of use of the AEDT is not sufficient on its own to conduct a statistically significant bias 
audit. The employment agency may rely on a bias audit using the historical data of other employers and 
employment agencies if it provides its 6 months of historical data to the independent auditor for use and 
consideration. The employment agency may also rely on a bias audit that uses test data. 
 
Example 3: An employer has been using an AEDT for 3 years and will soon need an updated bias audit. 
The employer has statistically significant data from its 3 years of use of the AEDT. The employer may 
rely on a bias audit conducted using historical data from multiple employers if it provides its 3 years of 
historical data to the independent auditor for use and consideration. The employer may also rely on a 
bias audit conducted using historical data from its own use of the AEDT, without any data from other 
employers or employment agencies. The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test 
data.  
 
§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of 
individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.

Document 11: 5 
 
 
Test data. “Test data” means data used to conduct a bias audit that is not historical data. 
§ 5-301 Bias Audit. 
(a) An employer or employment agency may not use or continue to use an AEDT if more than one year has 
passed since the most recent bias audit of the AEDT.  
(b) Where an AEDT selects candidates for employment or employees being considered for promotion to 
move forward in the hiring process or classifies them into groups, a bias audit must, at a minimum: 
(1) Calculate the selection rate for each category; 
(2) Calculate the impact ratio for each category; 
(3) Ensure that the calculations required in paragraphs (1) and (2) of this subdivision separately 
calculate the impact of the AEDT on: 
i. Sex categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of male candidates vs female candidates),  
ii. Race/Ethnicity categories (e.g., impact ratio for selection of Hispanic or Latino 
candidates vs Black or African American [Not Hispanic or Latino] candidates), and 
iii. intersectional categories of sex, ethnicity, and race (e.g., impact ratio for selection of 
Hispanic or Latino male candidates vs. Not Hispanic or Latino Black or African American 
female candidates). 
(4) Ensure that the calculations in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) of this subdivision are performed for 
each group, if an AEDT classifies candidates for employment or employees being considered 
for promotion into specified groups (e.g., leadership styles); and 
(5) Indicate the number of individuals the AEDT assessed that are not included in the required 
calculations because they fall within an unknown category. 
 
Example: An employer wants to use an AEDT to screen resumes and schedule interviews for a job 
posting. To do so, the employer must ensure that a bias audit of the AEDT was conducted no more than 
a year before the planned use of the AEDT. This bias audit is necessary even though the employer is not 
using the AEDT to make the final hiring decision, but only to screen at an early point in the application 
process. The employer asks the vendor for a bias audit.

§ 5-302 Data Requirements. 
(a) Historical Data. A bias audit conducted pursuant to section 5-301 of this Chapter must use historical 
data of the AEDT. The historical data used to conduct a bias audit may be from one or more employers 
or employment agencies that use the AEDT. However, an individual employer or employment agency 
may rely on a bias audit of an AEDT that uses the historical data of other employers or employment 
agencies only in the following circumstances: if such employer or employment agency provided historical 
data from its own use of the AEDT to the independent auditor conducting the bias audit or if such 
employer or employment agency has never used the AEDT. 
(b) Test Data. Notwithstanding the requirements of subdivision (a) of this section, an employer or 
employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data if insufficient historical data is available 
to conduct a statistically significant bias audit.

If there is insufficient historical data available to conduct a statistically significant bias audit of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency may rely on a bias audit that uses test data. The use of test data is related to the circumstances under which an employer or employment agency may conduct a bias audit of an AEDT. Therefore, the relationship between the definition of 'test data' and the requirements for a bias audit of an AEDT is that test data may be used in certain circumstances when historical data is not available to conduct a bias audit, as outlined in Local Law 144.

question: What are the differences and similarities between the requirements for publicly available information on the employment section of a website before the use of an AEDT and the options for an employer or employment agency to provide notice to a candidate for employment regarding the use of an AEDT?
reference_answer: Before the use of an AEDT, the employment section of a website must publicly provide the date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results. Additionally, employers or employment agencies have the options to provide notice on the employment section of their website, in a job posting, or via U.S. mail or e-mail. These requirements and options ensure transparency and communication regarding the use of an AEDT in the employment process.
reference_context:
Document 20: The employer may not rely on a bias audit conducted using test 
data.  
 
§ 5-303 Published Results. 
(a) Before the use of an AEDT, an employer or employment agency in the city must make the following 
publicly available on the employment section of their website in a clear and conspicuous manner:  
(1) 
The date of the most recent bias audit of the AEDT and a summary of the results, which shall 
include the source and explanation of the data used to conduct the bias audit, the number of 
individuals the AEDT assessed that fall within an unknown category, and the number of 
applicants or candidates, the selection or scoring rates, as applicable, and the impact ratios 
for all categories; and, 
(2) 
The distribution date of the AEDT.  
(b) The requirements of subdivision (a) of this section may be met with an active hyperlink to a website 
containing the required summary of results and distribution date, provided that the link is clearly identified 
as a link to results of the bias audit. 
(c) An employer or employment agency must keep the summary of results and distribution date posted for 
at least 6 months after its latest use of the AEDT for an employment decision.   
 
§ 5-304 Notice to Candidates and Employees.  
(a) The notice required by § 20-871(b)(1) of the Code must include instructions for how an individual can 
request an alternative selection process or a reasonable accommodation under other laws, if 
available. Nothing in this subchapter requires an employer or employment agency to provide an 
alternative selection process. 
(b) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to a candidate for employment who resides in the city by doing any of the following: 
(1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;  
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT.

alternative selection process.

notice to a candidate for employment who resides in the city by doing any of the following: 
(1) Provide notice on the employment section of its website in a clear and conspicuous manner 
at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT;  
(2) Provide notice in a job posting at least 10 business days before use of an AEDT; or, 
(3) Provide notice to candidates for employment via U.S. mail or e-mail at least 10 business days 
before use of an AEDT. 
(c) To comply with § 20-871(b)(1) and (2) of the Code, an employer or employment agency may provide 
notice to an employee being considered for promotion who resides in the city by doing any of the 
following: 
(1) Provide notice in a written policy or procedure that is provided to employees at least 10 
business days before use of an AEDT;

(d) To comply with § 20-871(b)(3) of the Code, an employer or employment agency must:
